required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Oxytocin Levels in Typically Developing Boys
clinical_study.official_title: Ontogenic Measurement of Plasma Oxytocin in Typically Developing Boys Using Extracted and Unextracted EIA Methods

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: Measuring basal levels of plasma oxytocin in individuals with typical development across childhood and adolescence using both extracted and unextracted EIA methods.

detailed_description.textblock: Measuring basal levels of plasma oxytocin in individuals with typical development across childhood and adolescence using both extracted and unextracted EIA methods. This study is necessary since there is great variability in reported plasma oxytocin in typically developing children from other studies as well as up to 1000 fold variability in such levels using different assay procedures. Further existing studies have not clearly described variation in levels with age. all samples will be taken in the afternoon.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline oxytocin level at visit 1 (time zero)
primary_outcome.description: 20 children in each of 3 age cohorts 3-6, 7-12, and 13-17 will participate. Plasma oxytocin levels will be taken at the screening appointment.

secondary_outcome.description: C reactive protein and cytokine panel

arm_group.description: This will include 10 typically developing boys age 3-6
This will include 10 typically developing boys age 7-12
This will include 10 typically developing boys age 13-17

study_pop.textblock: This population will be a community sample representative of the community of the area.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Between 3 and 17 years old, inclusive
- Consent of parent or guardian.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Exclusion Criteria for Healthy Control Participants:
- Female gender
- Evidence of a mental health diagnosis
- Evidence of significant medical condition (ie: renal, cardiovascular or genetic disease)
- First degree family member with an ASD diagnosis

facility.name: University of North Carolina Chapel Hill

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill
